body: this is mainly a release to support tokio 1.0. Otherwise, the only difference with the current 1.1.0 version is the connection timeout code, that adds a new member in `BackOffOptions`

title: Remove ack_tx from ConsumerEngine
body:
The `ConsumerEngine` uses the ack receiver to know when it should stop (Consumer object was dropped). Passing the sender into the engine introduced a bug where dropping the consumer object no longer stops the engine.

This PR changes the place inside the engine where the sender was used to eagerly ack the message instead. Can anyone comment on if this would cause any issues?

Fixes #119

title: handle active consumer change, end of topic messages
executor: Store an instance instead of using raw methods
body:
This allows some consumer of pulsar-rs to define a custom executor that can carry some state around

It also makes things easier when some software (vector being an exemple) already carries an object around to abstract the executor on top of some other one. This way we can just pass that object around.

title: Cleanup API
body:
Major changes: 
1. Everything is only constructible from a builder. This allows us to add improvements without breaking the API
2. The phantom types on the builders have been removed
3. Both consumers and producers handle partitions transparently
4. The same public consumer type is used for regex-matched consumers vs explicit topic consumers
5. The client's `send` is backed by the MultiTopicProducer
6. Tests cleaned up and simplified
7. All doc-tests compile
8. (most) implementation details are no longer public (`messages` still are).

title: Owned serialize
body: trying out a solution to avoid copies when serializing (cf https://github.com/wyyerd/pulsar-rs/issues/67#issuecomment-653703530 )

title: Reconnection
body: this PR starts the work to handle reconnections while keeping existing Producer and Consumer instances. Part of the difficulty comes from sharing the `Connection`: replacing the connection with a new one means mutable access to the fields of `ConnectionSender`. I could put a Mutex around `ConnectionSender` or some of its fields, but there's a risk of deadlock if I'm not careful with the async code. Another option would be to hide mutability in yet another task

title: move message deserialization outside of the consumer
body:
This is an attempt at making deserializing a bit easier to handle (types are easier to follow, no need to implement DeserializeMessage if we don't need it, etc). @stearnsc an opinion on this?

The basic idea is that instead of the consumer returning a message on which `DeserializeMessage::deserialize_message` was already called (and losing payload metadata at the same time), we separate the deserialize phase into a method on the message

title: async-std support
body:
first commit: remove the executor member, and instead get the executor statically (to do  `tokio::runtime::Handle::current().spawn(f)` with tokio and `task::spawn(f)` wih async-std).

@LucioFranco IIRC you did the initial work to make pulsar-rs generic over the executor (was that to support tokio 0.1 and tokio 0.2 in vector?). Will this change cause issues with the integration in vector?

From a user's point of view, the main change is this https://github.com/wyyerd/pulsar-rs/pull/88/files#diff-f5be2bf3fd69683200ad4f58e2550984R63

(and I'll add `new_tokio` an `new_async_std` methods to simplify that)

title: implement compression
body:
this commit chain will add support for compression and decompression:
- [x] LZ4
- [x] zlib
- [x] zstd
- [x] snappy

title: replace connection::Sender with a spawned task
body: this simplifies the code significantly (replacing a custom Future implementation with a 6 lines async block)

title: Consumer ack methods
body:
this PR follows #81 and implements the changes from #80.
It will fix #51 and #64 by making it explicit that a consumer must be alive to acknowledge (or nack) a message.

title: close the consumer asynchronously
body: First part of #80: closing the consumer asynchronously

title: Expose TokioExecutor
body: Currently creating a Pulsar instance within a tokio app is impossible given that TokioExecutor is private. This PR exposes it so that it can be used

title: [WIP]Consumer drop with lingering ack
body: this PR builds upon #71 and adds a test for #51. The test appears to pass, but I'm not convinced it is working properly, I'll investigate a bit more

title: Futures 0.3
body:
it is not finished yet, but at least it compiles and the tests run :smile: 
It includes dependency updates for bytes, prost, prost-derive, tokio, futures-timer and trust-dns-resolver since those were also converted to the new futures.
I converted a large part of the code to async/await since it solves some compilation issues, an overall it makes the code a bit easier to follow

title: Add support for batched messages
body:
Closes #59 

Adds support for batched messages:
- Batched messages are properly separated and exposed as single messages
- `AckHandler` now tracks batched messages to ack/nack only once when either all messages are acked or one is nacked

title: Generic Executor
body:
builds on #56 to thread through generic executors

Is this what you were going for @LucioFranco? It required quite a few changes. I removed some unneeded clones & conversions while I was at it.
